title: Assign a step to a worker group
content:
Worker groups

Many deployments can benefit from having more than a single worker in a specific environment. For example, this could be helpful if you are managing a remote data center where you need workers to be able to withstand the action execution load, or simply to ensure high availability of workers in that data center.

Therefore, OO includes the notion of a “worker group”. A group is a logical collection of workers, and a worker may belong to more than one group simultaneously. Having a worker group helps prevent bottlenecks, because a step can run on any of the workers in the group.

Groups can be created and workers assigned to groups in OO Central.

Assign a step to a worker group

In OO Workflow Designer, you can assign a specific step of a flow to a specific worker group or groups.

The steps can be from OO native content packs (Created using OO Desktop Studio) or CloudSlang content packs (Created using OO Workflow Designer).

To assign a specific step to a worker group, complete the following:

  1. In the Authoring pane, right-click the CloudSlang or the OO native step. A list of options is displayed.

  2. Select the Set Worker Group option. A new field will appear in the Step Properties>Inputs tab.

    Alternatively, click the Set Worker Group icon from the authoring pane to assign a step as a Set Worker Group.

  3. At the flow-level, for the variable worker_group, if you:
    1. Select Force override in subflows, and all the steps of the flow will be executed by the worker you have set.
    2. Do not select Force override in subflows; only steps that do not have a worker will be executed by the worker you have set.

  4.  Select the field input value and then click Save. The step is assigned to a worker group, and the CloudSlang code is also updated.

  5. The field values can be a constant, an expression or a flow variable, or a system property.
    In the following image of a CloudSlang code, the first step has a worker_group set from a flow variable, and the second one is set from a constant.
  6. Run a flow. Each step will be run on the specified worker group.
